TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE

GOVERNANCE AND POVERTY FORUMS
March 2001

ABBREVIATIONS
ADB – Asian Development Bank

In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.

I.  INTRODUCTION
1. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) made poverty reduction its overarching goal with
the Board’s approval of the poverty reduction strategy in November 1999.1 With the adoption of
both a new private sector development strategy,2 and later good governance medium-term
agenda and action plan,3 ADB clearly recognizes the contribution that the private sector and
good governance can make in reducing poverty in the region. To address these issues, ADB is
undertaking numerous initiatives as part of its business processes and technical assistance
(TA). The findings of these studies will be disseminated at various forums, including an annual
meeting seminar, to be held in May 2001. For this purpose, ADB will carry out a regional TA to
fund disseminating study findings and encouraging high-level discussions on the issues.4 ADB’s
RETA Screening Committee approved the TA on 18 December 2000. The TA framework is
provided in Appendix 1.
II.  BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE
2. The  poverty  reduction  strategy  emphasizes  the  importance  of  transport,
communications, and energy infrastructure as foundations for pro-poor, sustainable economic
growth, one of the strategic pillars of poverty reduction. To share fully in economic advancement
and human development, people need efficient transport and communications, and access to
electricity supply. ADB’s experience in many of its developing member countries (DMCs) has
shown that increasing the capacity of the primary transport network, electricity generation and
transmission, and communication network, are key to improving competitiveness and attracting
private investment. Investment in rural transport and rural electrification provides the rural poor
with better access to economic opportunities, including facilitating their access to production
inputs, reaching product markets, and having more available sources of employment. Rural
infrastructure also improves access to human development services and extension support, and
helps overcome problems of social exclusion due to remoteness.
3.  The link between private sector development and poverty reduction can be summarized
as follows:
(i)  sustainable job creation—the private sector’s contribution to poverty reduction
mainly comes through growth, employment, and income generation;
(ii)  creation of “fiscal space”—private infrastructure expenditures such as power,
water, roads, and telecommunications can allow governments to provide larger
budgets for social expenditures;
(iii)  availability  of  infrastructure  services  to  the  poor—in  their  bid  specifications,
governments can include public obligations directed mainly to the poor;
(iv)  regulation of private utilities—effective regulation can ensure pro-poor outcomes
for services through better access and lower prices;
(v)  lowered public debt—proceeds from privatization can be used to decrease public
debt, fund new expenditures, and share benefits with the general population; and
(vi)  responsible corporate citizenship—private companies can directly improve the
lives of poor people through the way they do business, by being sensitive to

social and environmental issues, health and safety, corruption, and the local
economy.
4.  Similarly, good governance is essential if infrastructure is to realize its potential for
reducing  poverty.  This  encompasses  all  aspects  of  infrastructure—including  planning,
construction, operation, and regulation. The procurement of infrastructure, often entailing large
contracts,  must  be  managed  judiciously  and  efficiently  for  the  potential  benefits  of  the
infrastructure to be realized. The quality and costs of transport and electricity supply, and their
geographical coverage and affordability to the poor, depend on having an appropriate regulatory
framework to provide for competition and operational efficiency.
5.  Moreover, overall governance is important in the public sector and corporate governance
is essential in the private sector. Good governance of corporations is a source of competitive
advantage and is critical to economic and social progress. With globalization, firms must tap
domestic and international capital markets in quantities and ways that were inconceivable even
a decade ago. Increasingly, individual investors, funds, banks, and other financial institutions
base their decisions not only on a company’s balance sheet and financial outlook, but also on its
social and environmental reputation and its governance. This growing need to access financial
resources, domestic and foreign, has brought corporate governance into prominence the world
over.
6.  Meanwhile, lessons drawn from the Asian financial crisis have pointed out the potential
risks  and  vulnerabilities  in  the  financial  system,  and  the  inherent  dangers  associated  with
growing globalization and integration of weakly regulated and supervised financial systems. In
response, the International Monetary Fund, the G-7,5 and other groups, including the Asia-
Pacific  Economic  Cooperation  (APEC)  Finance  Ministers  and  Central  Bank  Group,  have
underscored the need to strengthen financial systems, and have mandated the international
financial institutions to launch efforts to promote the development of sound and stable financial
systems. ADB, in collaboration with the Financial Stability Forum, will invite experts directly
involved in financial architecture to discuss the new international standards relating to practices
in banking, securities markets, and the insurance and accounting sectors. This collaborative
forum will include the views of representatives of international standard setting bodies and other
agencies and experts.
7.  ADB’s 34th Annual Meeting will be an ideal forum for bringing new policies that ADB is
currently implementing into the international discussion arena. Specifically, poverty reduction,
private sector development, good governance, and stable financial structure are some of the
major thrusts that ADB is addressing. Furthermore, the rapid globalization of the knowledge-
based economy presents enormous opportunities for the role of information and communication
technology (ICT) in accelerating growth and reducing poverty by promoting access to and use of
ICT. Following the high-level discussions of the G-7 in Okinawa, the seminar on ICT will
elaborate ways that ADB can strengthen DMCs’ ICT development as it continues to assist
DMCs in this area.
                                                
5 The G-7 countries are Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
A.  Objective
8. The TA will finance the six seminars and forums (paras. 11-12). Thus, the TA will (i)
promote  ADB’s  overarching  objective  of  poverty  reduction  and  linkages  to  infrastructure
development;  (ii)  enhance  ADB’s  major  thrust  of  private  sector  development;  and  (iii)
demonstrate the linkages of infrastructure investment, corporate governance, and ICT with
poverty  reduction.  In  addition,  the  TA  will  highlight  ADB’s  initiatives  in  capital  market
development; corporate governance through institutional strengthening of institutes of chartered
accountants; and support for chambers of commerce, which are key stakeholders in private
sector and capital markets development.
B.  Scope
9.  The  TA  includes  three  seminars  at  the  34th  Annual  Meeting:  (i)  Private  Sector
Development Strategy; (ii) The ICT Revolution: Can Asia Leapfrog Poverty Barriers?; and (iii)
Forum on the Implementation of International Financial Standards in Asia. In addition, the TA
covers the 3rd Asian Corporate Governance Roundtable, which will be held in Singapore on 4-6
April 2001; the 2nd World Chambers Congress in May 2001, which will include participation of
local  chambers  of  commerce  from  DMCs  such  as  Bangladesh,  Bhutan,  Cambodia,  Cook
Islands,  Kiribati,  Kyrgyz  Republic,  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic,  Maldives,  Mongolia,
Nepal, and Vanuatu; and the international Symposium on Assessing the Impact of Transport
and Energy Infrastructure on Poverty Reduction, also in 2001. The TA is expected to be
completed in December 2001.
C.  Cost Estimates and Financing Plan
10.  The estimated cost of the TA is $250,000, which will be financed on a grant basis from
the ADB-funded TA program. About $105,000 will cover the costs of three seminars at the
34th Annual  Meeting  in  Honolulu,  Hawaii;  $50,000  for  the  3rd  Asian  Corporate  Governance
Roundtable  in  Singapore;  $20,000  for  part  of  the  expenses  of  the  2nd  World  Chambers
Congress  in  Seoul,  Republic  of  Korea;  and  $75,000  for  the  international  Symposium  on
Assessing the Impact of Transport and Energy Infrastructure on Poverty Reduction. Detailed
cost estimates are provided in Appendix 2. The estimate provides for costs of travel, honoraria
for guest speakers and resource persons, report preparation, documentation, and the conduct
of the meetings.
D.  Implementation Arrangements
11.  ADB’s  Infrastructure  East  Department  (IED),  Infrastructure  West  Department  (IWD),
Office of Information Systems and Technology (OIST), and Private Sector Group (PSG) are
coordinating the annual meeting seminars on (i) Private Sector Development Strategy; (ii) The
ICT Revolution: Can Asia Leapfrog Poverty Barriers?; and (iii) Forum on the Implementation of
International Financial Standards in Asia. IWD will also cosponsor the 3rd Asian Corporate
Governance Roundtable in Singapore in April 2001, which will followup on the roundtable held
in Hong Kong, China in April 2000. The Asian Corporate Governance Roundtable was initiated
in an Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) meeting in Seoul,

4
Republic of Korea (March 1999), cosponsored by the Government of Japan and the World
Bank. This will be the second meeting in which ADB cosponsors an international conference on
corporate governance with OECD and the World Bank. ADB will bring in the Asian perspective
on the role of boards and stakeholders in corporate governance. The 3rd Asian Roundtable will
be  cohosted  by  the  Monetary  Authority  of  Singapore,  Singapore  Stock  Exchange,  and
Singapore Institute of Directors.
12.   In addition, ADB through IWD will support the 2nd World Chambers Congress in Seoul,
Republic of Korea, in May 2001. Participants will include representatives of local chambers of
commerce  from  various  DMCs.  The  congress  will  focus  on  themes  such  as  governance,
accountability, and other key crosscutting issues—all very much in line with ADB’s foci. The
congress will also provide ADB an additional platform for disseminating information about its
related activities through a booth and prominence in the write-ups for the World Chambers
Congress. Finally, following the completion of TA for Assessing the Impact of Transport and
Energy  Infrastructure  on  Poverty  Reduction,6  IWD  will  coordinate  in  2001  an  International
Symposium including national workshops in the TA countries.
13.  Any consultants employed under the TA will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s
Guidelines for the Use of Consultants and other arrangements acceptable to ADB should there
be a need to engage domestic consultants.
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION
14. The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the
provision  of  the  technical  assistance,  on  a  grant  basis,  in  an  amount  not  exceeding  the
equivalent of $250,000 for the purpose of the Governance and Poverty Forums, and hereby
reports such action to the Board.
